commits.message:
docs: Add comprehensive research preview status notes

Created claude-web-research-preview-notes.md with:
- Current implementation status and gap analysis
- Completed features review (scanner, database, LLM, reporting)
- Test coverage summary (64 tests passing)
- Technical health assessment (~2,136 LOC)
- Prioritized roadmap for next steps
- Risk assessment and mitigation strategies

Key findings:
- Core MVP features 80% complete
- All tests passing, code quality high
- Ready for Priority 1: Polish and public release
- Recommended focus: documentation, distribution, performance

refactor: Reduce function arguments using parameter structs

Properly fixed the clippy::too_many_arguments warning by introducing
parameter grouping structs instead of suppressing the warning.

Changes:
- Created CliContext struct to group verbose and dry_run flags
- Created FilterOptions struct to group repository filter flags
  (recent, stale, active, all)
- Refactored handle_analyze_command from 8 params to 4 params
- Refactored handle_scan_command from 4 params to 3 params
- Refactored handle_report_command from 6 params to 3 params
- Refactored handle_config_command from 3 params to 3 params (using ctx)
- Refactored analyze_batch from 7 params to 3 params
- Refactored analyze_single_repository from 4 params to 3 params
- Removed #[allow(clippy::too_many_arguments)] directive

All functions now follow Rust best practices (‚â§7 parameters).
All tests pass and clippy reports zero warnings.

This eliminates technical debt from the previous commit where the
warning was only suppressed rather than properly addressed.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

chore: Run cargo fmt and fix all clippy warnings

Applied automated code quality improvements to meet Rust best practices:

Code Formatting (cargo fmt):
- Applied consistent formatting across all source files
- Fixed line lengths and indentation
- Reformatted long function calls and match statements

Clippy Fixes:
- Removed redundant closures (use function directly in map_err)
- Removed useless format! macro (use .to_string() or direct string)
- Changed &PathBuf to &Path in function signatures (more idiomatic)
- Used .flatten() instead of nested if-let for iterator unwrapping
- Added #[allow(clippy::too_many_arguments)] for analyze command
  (refactoring to reduce params would require larger structural changes)

All tests pass (64 tests) and code compiles without warnings.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

fix: Canonicalize repository paths to prevent duplicates

Repository paths are now canonicalized (converted to absolute paths)
before being stored in the database. This prevents the same repository
from being stored multiple times with different path representations
(e.g., relative vs absolute paths like "../assist" vs
"/Users/mike/github/softwarewrighter/assist").

Changes:
- GitAnalyzer now calls path.canonicalize() before storing
- All paths in the database are now consistent absolute paths
- Eliminates duplicate entries in reports and database queries
- Added .claude/ to .gitignore for local settings

Testing:
- All existing tests pass
- Verified that rescanning eliminates duplicates (28‚Üí27 repos)
- Active repos report reduced from 12‚Üí11 (duplicate removed)

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

feat: Add dry-run mode (-n/--dry-run) to prevent destructive operations

Implements a comprehensive dry-run mode that shows what would be done
without actually making changes. This is useful for verifying commands
before execution, especially for database writes and LLM API calls.

Features:
- Global -n/--dry-run flag available on all commands
- Visual indicator (üîç DRY-RUN MODE) when enabled
- Scan command: Shows repositories that would be stored in database
- Analyze command: Shows LLM analysis plan without API calls
  - Single repo: Shows Ollama connection details and analysis plan
  - Batch mode: Lists all repos that would be analyzed
- Config --edit: Shows editor that would be opened without launching it

All database writes and LLM API calls are skipped in dry-run mode,
while repository discovery and validation still occur to provide
accurate preview of what would happen.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

Merge pull request #8 from softwarewrighter/claude/summarize-project-purpose-011CUz6rxmwe3pN7jk6HtD6u

Claude/summarize project purpose 011 c uz6rxmwe3p n7jk6 ht d6u

feat: Add batch analysis support to analyze command

Extended the analyze command to support batch analysis with filters:

**New Batch Analysis Modes:**
- `assist analyze --recent` - Batch analyze recently active repos
- `assist analyze --stale` - Batch analyze stale repos
- `assist analyze --active` - Batch analyze repos with uncommitted changes
- `assist analyze --all` - Batch analyze all repos

**Features:**
- Smart skipping: Won't re-analyze unless --force is specified
- Progress tracking: Shows [1/10], [2/10], etc. as it processes
- Summary report: Shows analyzed, skipped, and error counts
- Respects max_repos_in_summary configuration limit
- Silent analysis mode (verbose=false) for batch operations

**Single Repo Mode (unchanged):**
- `assist analyze ~/path/to/repo` - Analyze single repository
- `assist analyze ~/path/to/repo --force` - Force re-analysis

**Example Output:**
```
Batch Analysis: 5 repositories

[1/5] Analyzing: assist
   Already analyzed (use --force to re-analyze)

[2/5] Analyzing: my-app
Checking Ollama connection...
Connected to Ollama using model: llama3.2
Generating analysis...
Analysis complete!

============================================================
Batch Analysis Complete
  Analyzed: 4
  Skipped:  1
```

All 64 tests passing.

fix: Enhance --active flag with detailed status and explanations

Fixed and enhanced the --active flag to properly detect and explain repository activity:

**Bug Fix:**
- Fixed has_uncommitted_changes() to correctly filter out IGNORED and CURRENT files
- Now properly identifies only repos with actual changes

**Enhanced Status Detection:**
- Created RepoStatus struct with comprehensive status information:
  * Untracked files count
  * Modified tracked files count
  * Staged files count
  * Current branch name
  * Upstream tracking branch
  * Commits ahead of upstream
  * Commits behind upstream

- get_detailed_status() method captures full git status
- is_active() checks for any form of activity
- get_activity_summary() provides human-readable reasons

**Enhanced Report Output:**
For --active reports, now shows:
- Why each repository is considered active
- One-line status summary (e.g., "2 modified files, 1 commit ahead")
- Branch tracking information with upstream
- Separate formatting for terminal, JSON, and Markdown

**Example Output:**
```
Active Repositories
2 repositories with uncommitted changes or divergence

1. assist (softwarewrighter)
   Path: /Users/mike/github/assist
   Status: 2 modified files, 1 staged file, 3 commits ahead of upstream
   Branch: main -> origin/main
   Last Commit: 2025-01-10 14:23:45 (0 days ago)
```

All 64 tests passing.

Merge pull request #7 from softwarewrighter/claude/summarize-project-purpose-011CUz6rxmwe3pN7jk6HtD6u

feat: Implement --active flag and analyze command with Ollama

feat: Implement --active flag and analyze command with Ollama

Implemented full analyze functionality:

**--active flag for report command:**
- Dynamically checks all repositories for uncommitted changes
- Uses GitAnalyzer.has_uncommitted_changes() to detect modified files
- Filters repositories with uncommitted changes
- Respects max_repos_in_summary configuration limit

**Ollama LLM integration:**
- Created llm module with OllamaClient
- Health check to verify Ollama connectivity
- Repository analysis with context from README and recent commits
- Configurable model and host settings
- 120-second timeout for LLM operations

**Analyze command:**
- Analyzes single repository at specified path
- Reads README file (up to 2000 chars) for context
- Extracts last 10 commit messages for recent activity
- Connects to Ollama to generate comprehensive analysis
- Stores analysis in database with timestamps
- Prevents duplicate analysis unless --force is used
- Verbose mode for debugging Ollama connection
- Pretty-printed results with model and date information

**Database integration:**
- Automatically adds repository to database if not present
- Links analysis to repository record
- Retrieves cached analysis on subsequent runs

All 64 tests passing.

feat: Implement report command with multiple output formats

feat: Implement report command with multiple output formats

Added comprehensive report functionality:

- Database methods:
  - Added get_all_repositories() method to fetch all repos with optional limit

- Report command features:
  - --recent: Show recently active projects (within configured days)
  - --stale: Show stale projects (no commits in configured days)
  - --active: Placeholder for uncommitted changes (shows all for now)
  - --all: Show all repositories without filters
  - Default behavior: Show recent repositories

- Output formats:
  - Terminal: Colorized, formatted list with details
  - JSON: Machine-readable structured output
  - Markdown: Documentation-friendly format

- Uses configuration settings:
  - reporting.days_for_recent: Days to consider recent
  - reporting.max_repos_in_summary: Maximum repos to show

All tests passing (62 tests).

feat: Add comprehensive diagnostics for database file creation

feat: Add comprehensive diagnostics for database file creation

Added detailed debugging output to identify SQLite connection issues:
- Check directory permissions and metadata
- Test write permissions by creating a test file
- Attempt to manually create database file if it doesn't exist

This will help identify whether the issue is:
- Permission-related
- SQLite library issue
- File system access problem

Merge pull request #4 from softwarewrighter/claude/summarize-project-purpose-011CUz6rxmwe3pN7jk6HtD6u

feat: Add verbose flag for detailed debugging output

feat: Add verbose flag for detailed debugging output

Adds -v/--verbose flag to all commands (global flag). When used with
'scan', it shows:
- Configuration loading steps
- Database path and URL generation
- Exact SQLite connection string
- File permissions and existence checks
- Step-by-step progress through scanning
- Detailed error information

Usage: cargo run -- scan -v

This will help diagnose the database connection issue by showing
exactly what URL is being generated and where the error occurs.

Merge pull request #3 from softwarewrighter/claude/summarize-project-purpose-011CUz6rxmwe3pN7jk6HtD6u

fix: Correct SQLite URL format to avoid four slashes

fix: Correct SQLite URL format to avoid four slashes

The previous fix used sqlite:///{path} which resulted in four slashes
for Unix absolute paths (e.g., sqlite:////Users/mike/db.sqlite).

The correct format is sqlite://{path} which gives:
- sqlite:///Users/mike/db.sqlite (3 slashes) for absolute paths
- sqlite://./relative.db (2 slashes) for relative paths

This fixes the 'unable to open database file' error on macOS/Unix.

Merge pull request #2 from softwarewrighter/claude/summarize-project-purpose-011CUz6rxmwe3pN7jk6HtD6u

fix: Use correct SQLite URL format for absolute paths

fix: Use correct SQLite URL format for absolute paths

SQLite URLs require three slashes (sqlite:///) for absolute paths
and two slashes (sqlite://) for relative paths. This fixes the
'unable to open database file' error when running assist scan.

Fixes database connection issues on macOS and other systems where
the database is stored at an absolute path like ~/.assist/assist.db

docs: Add comprehensive usage guide

Created detailed user documentation covering:
- Installation and initial setup instructions
- Configuration for different machines and ownership structures
- All core commands with examples and expected output
- Common workflows (daily status, weekly review, project recovery)
- Advanced usage with jq, fzf, and database queries

The guide provides practical examples for both personal (wrightmikea) and business (softwarewrighter) repository management across multiple machines.

feat: Implement TDD foundation with config and database modules

Established Test-Driven Development workflow and implemented core modules
following red-green-refactor cycle with comprehensive test coverage.

## Development Process Documentation
- Created docs/process.md with TDD methodology and best practices
- Defined red-green-refactor cycle workflow
- Established code quality standards and CI/CD guidelines
- Added pre-commit checks and security checklist

## Test Infrastructure
- Set up test_helpers module with utilities for:
  - Creating test git repositories with various states
  - Mock database setup
  - Test configuration generation
  - Mock Ollama responses

## Error Handling Module
- Comprehensive error types with thiserror
- Context wrapping for better error messages
- Type conversions for external error types
- 100% test coverage

## Configuration Module (12 tests, all passing)
- TOML-based configuration parsing and validation
- Support for multiple ownership structures (personal/business)
- Path expansion for home directory
- Ollama server configuration with failover support
- Default values with override capabilities
- Fixed clippy warnings (renamed from_str to from_toml_str)

## Database Module (22 tests, all passing)
- SQLite integration with sqlx
- Three core tables: repositories, analyses, scan_history
- Full CRUD operations for repository management
- Analysis storage with LLM results
- Scan history tracking
- Connection pooling and health checks
- Support for in-memory databases (testing)
- Fixed chrono DateTime binding issues

## Code Quality
- All modules pass clippy with no warnings
- Consistent error handling patterns
- Comprehensive documentation with examples
- Following Rust API guidelines

Next steps: Implement scanner module for git repository discovery.

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>

feat: Initial project structure for Assist CLI tool

Establish foundation for git repository management assistant with comprehensive
documentation and Rust project setup.

## Summary
- Created complete project documentation (architecture, PRD, implementation plan)
- Set up Rust project structure with CLI framework using clap
- Configured dependencies for all planned features
- Implemented basic command structure (scan, report, analyze, config, status)

## Documentation
- docs/architecture.md: System design with modular architecture, database schema,
  and component descriptions
- docs/PRD.md: Product requirements with functional/non-functional requirements,
  use cases, and success metrics
- docs/plan.md: 10-week implementation roadmap with sprint breakdown and milestones
- README.md: User-facing documentation with installation and usage instructions

## Technical Setup
- Configured Cargo.toml with all necessary dependencies:
  - CLI: clap for command parsing
  - Database: sqlx with SQLite support
  - Git: git2 for repository operations
  - LLM: reqwest for Ollama API integration
  - UI: indicatif, colored, comfy-table for terminal output
- Implemented placeholder CLI commands with proper argument handling
- Set up comprehensive .gitignore for Rust projects

## Project Goals
Assist will help manage multiple git repositories across different ownership
structures (personal vs business) and machines, providing:
- Automatic repository discovery and tracking
- Local SQLite database for metadata storage
- LLM-powered project analysis via Ollama
- Rich reporting capabilities
- Multi-machine configuration support

Next steps: Implement core modules following the architecture plan.

test: add comprehensive tests for -s flag without arguments

- `ask -s list` explicitly lists shortcuts

Changes:
- Modified CLI to accept -s without a value (defaults to "list")
- Added 4 new unit tests in cli.rs for shortcut arg parsing
- Added 6 integration tests that run the actual binary
- All 55 unit tests pass
- All 6 integration tests pass

The -s flag now uses clap's num_args and default_missing_value
features to make the shortcut argument optional while maintaining
backward compatibility with `-s <name>` usage.

Review Ask Project Status and Next Steps

feat: implement comprehensive usage tracking and cost calculation

Major Features:
- Add full usage tracking with token counts and cost calculation
- Implement --usage-report CLI flag to display usage statistics
- Create usage.rs module with UsageEntry, UsageStats, and reporting
- Track input/output tokens from OpenAI and Anthropic API responses
- Calculate costs based on config.toml token prices
- Log usage to ~/.local/share/ask/usage.jsonl (configurable)

Implementation Details:
- Added chrono dependency for timestamp support
- Created QueryResponse struct to wrap API responses with usage info
- Updated query_openai and query_anthropic to return QueryResponse with tokens
- Modified query_ollama to return QueryResponse (no token tracking available)
- Added automatic usage logging after successful API calls in main.rs
- Verbose mode now shows token usage and cost per query
- Usage report displays stats by platform and model with aggregated costs

Usage Tracking Features:
- Tracks platform, model, input/output tokens, and timestamp
- Calculates cost per query using config token prices
- Marks local models (Ollama) as electrical_only (zero API cost)
- Aggregates statistics by platform and model
- JSONL format for easy parsing and appending
- Supports tilde expansion in log file paths (~/...)

CLI Changes:
- Added --usage-report flag to display usage statistics
- Updated help documentation to include new flags
- Fixed doc tests to use response.text instead of response directly

Testing:
- All 42 unit tests pass
- All 21 doc tests pass
- Zero clippy warnings
- Added usage module tests for UsageEntry and UsageStats

Files Modified:
- Cargo.toml: Added chrono dependency
- src/lib.rs: Exported usage module
- src/usage.rs: New module (280+ lines)
- src/models.rs: Added QueryResponse struct
- src/client.rs: Updated to return QueryResponse
- src/openai.rs: Extract and return token usage
- src/anthropic.rs: Extract and return token usage
- src/main.rs: Added usage logging and --usage-report handling
- src/cli.rs: Added --usage-report flag, updated documented help

feat: implement Anthropic Claude support and fallback logic

Major Features:
- Add full Anthropic Claude API integration with query_anthropic() function
- Implement comprehensive fallback logic: primary ‚Üí backup models ‚Üí backup platform
- Add --anthropic-key CLI argument for API key specification
- Support all three platforms: Ollama, OpenAI, and Anthropic

Implementation Details:
- Created anthropic.rs module with API client for Claude models
- Added Anthropic request/response models (AnthropicMessage, AnthropicRequest, etc.)
- Updated client.rs to route Anthropic queries to new query_anthropic function
- Enhanced dry-run mode to show Anthropic request format with proper headers
- Fixed dry-run to work without API keys (was incorrectly requiring keys)

Fallback Logic:
- Try primary model on primary platform first
- On failure, iterate through backup models on same platform
- If all fail, switch to backup platform and try its default model
- Finally, try backup platform's backup models as last resort
- Verbose mode shows detailed fallback progression

Testing:
- All 40 unit tests pass
- All 21 doc tests pass
- Zero clippy warnings
- Tested dry-run mode with all three platforms (ollama, openai, anthropic)
- Updated test_anthropic_unsupported ‚Üí test_anthropic_missing_api_key

Documentation:
- Added comprehensive doc comments for all new functions
